revision.text:
'''RosUkrEnergo''' is a [[Swiss]]-registered venture company that transports [[natural gas]] from [[Turkmenistan]] to [[Eastern Europe|East European countries]]. 50% of the company is owned by [[Gazprom]], through its daughter Swiss-registered Rosgas Holding A.G., and another 50% by Swiss-registered private company Centragas Holding A.G., acting on behalf of a consortium of GDF Group<ref>[http://groupdf.com/about.asp Official website of GDF group]</ref><ref>[http://www.democracy.ru/article.php?id=1057 Сомнительный посредник - Демократия.Ру]</ref><ref>[http://www.rusenergy.com/newssystem/opened/37/20060426/436603.htm Стали известны хозяева РосУкрЭнерго]</ref><ref>[http://www.oxfordbusinessgroup.com/weekly01.asp?id=3638 Emerging Markets Economic Briefings]</ref> owned by [[Dmytro Firtash]] and {{ill|Ivan Fursin|uk|Фурсін Іван Геннадійович}}.<ref>[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-241453.html UNIAN - Nemtsov: Russian part in RosUkrEnergo looks as improper as Ukrainian one]</ref>
Before [[2009 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute]], it was the sole importer of natural gas from [[Gazprom]] reselling it to [[Naftogaz Ukrainy]].
==History== The company was created in July 2004 in a deal by former [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] and his [[Russian President|Russian counterpart]] [[Vladimir Putin]] to replace [[Eural Trans Gas]].<ref name="timelineRosUkrEnergo">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/96310/ Nation’s gas trade has volatile history rife with murky dealings], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 4, 2011)</ref> Until 2006 the company acted as a middleman between Turkmenistan and Ukraine. The company also sells Turkmenistan gas to [[Poland]]. Due to an agreement between Gazprom and Naftogaz, from 2006 till January 2009 the company supplied all of Ukraine's natural gas imports from [[Russia]] and other Central Asian countries, in addition to Turkmenistan. On October 24, 2008 [[Gazprom]] and Ukraine's national energy company [[Naftogaz]] signed a long-term cooperation deal in which was stated that Ukraine will receive Russian natural gas directly from Gazprom and Naftogaz will be the sole importer of Russian natural gas.<ref>[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-280400.html Gazprom, Naftogaz sign long-term cooperation deal]</ref>
After weeks of disputes the head of Gazprom Alexei Miller and the head of [[Naftohaz Ukrainy]] Oleh Dubyna signed the 10-year agreement on natural gas supplies to Ukraine for the period of 2009-2019 on 19 January 2009.<ref name=UNA190109> {{Cite news |title = Ukraine, Russia Agree On Gas Supplies To Ukraine For 2009-2019 |publisher = Ukrainian News Agency |date = 2009-01-19 |url = http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/174732.html |accessdate = 2009-01-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130105053149/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/174732.html |archivedate = 2013-01-05 |df = }} </ref><ref name=Reuters190109A> {{Cite news | title = Russia and Ukraine sign 10-year gas supply deal | author = Oleg Shchedrov; Ron Popeski | publisher = Reuters | date =2009-01-19 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE5062Q520090119?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true | accessdate = 2009-01-19}} </ref><ref name=BBC190109> {{Cite news | title = Russia and Ukraine sign gas deal | publisher = BBC News | date =2009-01-19 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7836736.stm | accessdate = 2009-01-19}} </ref> It was agreed that RosUkrEnergo will no longer supply all of Ukraine's natural gas imports from Russia and other Central Asian countries. A claim of a $600 million debt of Naftohaz to RosUkrEnergo was also dropped.<ref name=UNA190109/>
On March 4, 2009 Officers of the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) and the Alfa special police unit searched the headquarters of Naftohaz Ukrainy in a case against officials of Naftohaz Ukrainy on embezzlement of 6.3 billion cubic meters of transit [[natural gas]],<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/184429.html SBU Officers Leave Building Of Naftohaz On Completing Investigating Actions], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (March 4, 2009)</ref> according to [[Valerii Khoroshkovskyi]], first deputy chairman of the Security Service of Ukraine, the RosUkrEnergo Company and a number of Verkhovna Rada’s deputies had filed in a claim against Naftohaz Ukrainy.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/184592.html Khoroshkovskyi Unveils Reasons Behind RosUkrEnergo’s And Verkhovna Rada Deputies’ Claims Against Misappropriating 6.3 Billion Cubic Meters Of Gas], [[Ukrainian News Agency]], (March 5, 2009)</ref> On March 17, 2009 a criminal case was filed against officials of the Naftohaz Ukrainy national joint-stock company on suspicion of stealing 6.3 billion cubic meters of natural gas intended for transit through Ukraine by the SBU.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/186573.html SBU Sends Criminal Case Against Naftohaz Ukrainy Officials Accused Of Stealing 6.3 Billion Cubic Meters Of Gas To Prosecutors], [[Ukrainian News Agency]], (March 17, 2009)</ref>
On March 30, 2010 an [[international arbitration]] court in [[Stockholm]] ordered Naftohas Ukrainy to pay RosUkrEnergo around $200 million as a penalty for various breaches of supply, transit and storage contracts.<ref name=Stockholm/> On June 8, 2010 the Stockholm Arbitration Tribunal ordered Naftohaz to return 11 bcm of natural gas to RosUkrEnergo and that RosUkrEnergo would receive from Naftohaz a further 1.1 bcm of natural gas in lieu of RosUkrEnergo's entitlement to penalties for breach of contract.<ref name=Stockholm>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/business/bus_general/detail/69022/ Stockholm court obliges Naftogaz to return 12.1 billion cubic meters of gas to RosUkrEnergo], [[Kyiv Post]] (June 8, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/business/bus_general/detail/70879/ BYuT publishes documents on sales of disputed 11 billion cubic meters of gas by Gazprom to Naftogaz], [[Kyiv Post]] (June 25, 2010)</ref> On April 26, 2011 former [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] sued [[Dmytro Firtash]] and RosUkrEnergo in a [[U.S. District Court]] in [[Manhattan]] accusing them of "defrauding Ukraine's citizenry" by manipulating an arbitration court ruling, "undermining the rule of law in Ukraine" in connection with the 2010 international arbitration court ruling in Stockholm.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/27/ukraine-naftogaz-lawsuit-idUSN276396520110427 Ukrainian ex-PM sues gas company, businessman in US court], [[Reuters]] (April 27, 2011)</ref>
==Eural Trans Gas== '''Eural Trans Gas''' (ETG) was an energy company registered in [[Budapest]], Hungary, on December 6, 2002. It was suspected of acting as a [[Gazprom]] front. Andras Knopp, a former Hungarian communist cultural functionary with no knowledge of the gas business, became director of the company. The registered owner was Dmytro Firtash, an obscure Ukrainian national who reportedly had little if any known assets. Yet the person received almost $300 million in credits from Russian banks.<ref name="gazpromeuropeanweb">[http://ua-energy.org/uploads/library/analitics/FULL_GazpromsWeb.pdf Gazprom’s European Web]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. The Jamestown Foundation. February 2009.</ref>
ETG maintained an account at a Budapest branch of Vienna's [[Raiffeisen Bank]] and had a number of accounts in Vienna's [[Meinl Bank]].<ref name="gazpromeuropeanweb"/>
==Owners and allegations of criminal connections== Former Ukrainian Prime-Minister Yulia Tymoshenko stated in November 2006, the company is controlled by notorious Ukrainian-born Jewish [[Russian mafia]] boss [[Semion Mogilevich]],<ref>According to Tymoshenko ''"we have no doubts whatsoever that the man named [[Semyon Mogilevich|Mogilevich]] is behind the whole operation called RosUkrEnergo"'', see [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/panorama/6121508.stm The High Price of Gas] by [[BBC News]] (aired November 5, 2006)</ref> while in 2009 Vladimir Putin was quoted as claiming that RosUkrEnergo is owned by a business ally of [[Viktor Yushchenko]].<ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/09/news/gazprom.php Russia and Ukraine reach pact on gas deliveries], International Herald Tribune, January 9, 2009</ref> The Ukrainian investigation into RosUkrEnergo begun during Tymoshenko's previous term as Prime Minister was closed after she lost her position as Prime Minister in September 2005.<ref>[http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/303006.htm Mogilevich Arrested With Arbat Boss], The Moscow Times, January 28, 2008</ref> According to a document uncovered during the [[United States diplomatic cables leak]] US-diplomats shared Tymoshenko's suspicions.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/91986/ U.S. official: Austrian bank’s ties to RosUkrEnergo suspicious], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 3, 2010)</ref>
In April 2006, London-based corruption watchdog [[Global Witness]] published a report focusing on RosUkrEnergo and other transit companies that have acted as intermediaries between Turkmenistan, Russia and Ukraine. The report highlighted the many links in personnel between RosUkrEnergo and the previous intermediary Eural Trans Gas. According to the report, Israeli lawyer Zeev Gordon had registered Eural Trans Gas on behalf of Ukrainian businessman Dmytro Firtash.<ref>[http://www.globalwitness.org/media_library_get.php/296/its_a_gas_april_2006_lowres.pdf It’s a Gas—Funny Business in the Turkmen-Ukraine Gas Trade]</ref> Also in late April 2006, ''[[Izvestia]]'' reported that the primary shareholder of RosUkrEnergo is Dmytro Firtash. The report stated that he owned 90% of CentraGas Holding, equaling 45% of RosUkrEnergo. The report stated that a further owner is another Ukrainian businessman Ivan Fursin, the primary shareholder of the [[Odessa Film Studio]] and an owner of Misto-bank. His stake was revealed to be 10% of CentraGas and therefore a 5% owner of RosUkrEnergo.<ref>[http://izvestia.ru/economic/article3092391/ Известия.Ру: Кто владеет украинским газом]</ref>
==Profits== RosUkrEnergo reported a 2005 profit of $755 million and paid $735 million in dividends.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.rosukrenergo.ch/eng/pub/business.html ROSUKRENERGO - Business<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The company's 2006 profit is listed at over $785 million.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
RosUkrEnergo profit for January–September 2007 is reported at $213 million.<ref>[http://www.gazprom.ru/articles/article26995.shtml ОАО «Газпром» | Акционерам и инвесторам / Отчеты / Промежуточная финансовая отчетность 30.09.2007<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The company makes its profit on re-exporting gas to Europe. The size of the profit is defined by Gazprom through the export allowances of about 9 billion cubic meters a year.<ref>[http://www.rosukrenergo.ch/eng/pub/business/financial_data.html ROSUKRENERGO - Business - Financial data<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> RosUkrEnergo supplies gas to the Hungarian gas distributor [[Emfesz]], for example, which is also controlled by Firtash via his holding company [[Group DF]].
Effectively, by engaging in this supply scheme Gazprom transfers profits from its shareholders to the shareholders of RosUkrEnergo.
==Management== (As of October 2007<ref>[http://www.rosukrenergo.ch/eng/pub/company/management.html ROSUKRENERGO - Company - Management<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>)
Board of Directors: *[[Lars Haussmann]] (President of the Board of Directors) *[[Hans Baumgartner (businessman)|Hans Baumgartner]]
Executive Directors: *[[Konstantin Chuychenko]] *[[Dmitry Glebko]]
Coordination Committee: *Representing [[Gazprom]] **[[Valery Golubev]] **[[Alexander Medvedev]] **[[Stanislav Tsygankov]] **[[Sergey Khomyakov]] *Representing [[Centragas]] **[[Dmytro Firtash]] **David Brown - former director of [[British Gas plc|British Gas]] **[[Robert Shetler-Jones]] **[[Hanno Schatzmann]]
==See also== *[[Russia-Ukraine gas dispute]] *[[List of Gazprom subsidiaries]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070207020157/http://www.rosukrenergo.ch/ Official website] *[http://www.globalwitness.org/media_library_detail.php/479/en/its_a_gas._funny_business_in_the_turkmen_ukraine_g Global Witness Report] *[http://groupdf.com/centragas.asp Group DF - Centragas]
{{Group DF}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} '''Sokwanele''' is a popular protest [[resistance movement|underground movement]] based in [[Zimbabwe]]. They are pro-democracy, and they embrace supporters of all pro-democratic political parties, [[civic engagement|civic]] organisations and institutions. Sokwanele is committed to challenging and confronting – through [[non-violent]] activism – the way in which the ruling party, [[Zanu-PF]], governs Zimbabwe. Sokwanele is not affiliated to the opposition [[Movement for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai|Movement for Democratic Change]] (MDC) at all; in fact, the group's website very clearly states that they do not aspire to political office.
Sokwanele means 'enough is enough' in [[Sindebele language|Ndebele]]; the [[Shona language|Shona]] equivalent of the name is '[[Zvakwana]]'.
Sokwanele communicates with its supporters primarily via a [[newsletter]] that people can subscribe to online. They also have a website, and they run a regularly updated blog entitled ''This is Zimbabwe''. The government has imposed very tight restrictions on the media in Zimbabwe, and very few newspapers or radio stations that are critical of the government are permitted to operate. Sokwanele's communications provide a critical and impartial assessment of the government's actions, regularly reporting on corruption, human rights violations and bad [[governance]].
Sokwanele closely monitored, in the 22 weeks leading up to the [[parliamentary]] elections on 31 March 2005, the government's compliance with the [[Southern African Development Community]] (SADC) [[Protocol (diplomacy)|protocol]] 'Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections'. The protocol was agreed by SADC leaders in [[Mauritius]] on 17 August 2004 and Zimbabwe was one of the signatories. Sokwanele circulated their weekly assessments through a special newsletter entitled 'Mauritius Watch'. Their final report based on the mounting evidence of non-compliance concluded that the elections were deeply flawed and did not satisfy the SADC principles and guidelines, and therefore could not possibly be considered 'free and fair'. They reached this conclusion before the elections took place.
On [[election|polling]] day itself, Sokwanele blogged regular updates from [[activists]] on the ground who alerted them to unscrupulous government activities which included refusing access to polling agents from the main opposition party, imprisoning MDC agents, incommunicado, after the vote; and controlling all forms of communication to and from the polling stations. They also reported on the difficulty that some [[voters]] had in trying to vote, and reports from voters of the presence of dead relatives on the [[voter's roll]]. On the basis of this evidence, after the voting was over, Sokwanele went on to produce a report that detailed the hour by hour events on polling day into how they allege the government comprehensively [[Vote rigging|rigged]] the elections.
More recently, Sokwanele has written several [[essay|articles]] critical of the government's '[[Operation Murambatsvina]] (Operation Drive Out Trash).' Using [[Flickr]], Sokwanele has also compiled a set of photographs depicting the impact of Operation Murambatsvina on ordinary Zimbabwean civilians.
==External links== '''Sokwanele – key links''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050617002341/http://www.sokwanele.com/index.html Sokwanele website] [https://web.archive.org/web/20050719080431/http://www.zvakwana.org/ (''also see Zvakwana'')] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050709031454/http://www.sokwanele.com/blog/blog.html ''This is Zimbabwe'' – Sokwanele blog] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051219224116/http://www.sokwanele.com/articles/sokwanele/whathappenedonthursnight_5april2005.html 'What happened on Thursday night' : An account of how ZANU PF rigged the Parliamentary Elections] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050705075622/http://www.sokwanele.com/articles/sokwanele/mwatch_archive.html Archive of Mauritius Watch articles] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/59509188@N00/ Sokwanele on Flickr] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050403221900/http://www.sokwanele.com/join.html Subscribe to the Sokwanele newsletter]
'''Media reports''' * [https://www.theguardian.com/zimbabwe/article/0,,1504010,00.html Thrown on the scrapheap] * [https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,1454198,00.html Report claims evidence of Mugabe rigging] * [https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,1451939,00.html Enough is enough] * [http://www.afrol.com/News2003/index_zim009.htm Zimbabweans making noise for freedom] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4136063.stm Zimbabwe's fight for a free voice] * [http://www.zimbabwesituation.com/may11_2004.html#link7 "We are everywhere" Says Shadowy Pro-Democracy Group] * [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/international/story/0,6903,1243066,00.html Mugabe is spooked by the letter Z] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071006054757/http://www.zwnews.com/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=9047 Police hunt Zvakwana] * [http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=84&art_id=qw1078322581496B252&set_id=1 US is 'fighting Zimbabwe with condoms'] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20041026123400/http://www.theindependent.co.zw/news/2004/January/Friday30/1926.html Police raid MDC Byo offices again]
'''Other useful links''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050328092350/http://www.zanupfpub.co.zw/ Zanu-PF] * [http://www.mdczimbabwe.org/ Movement for Democratic Change] * [http://www.sadc.int/index.php SADC]

[[Django Reinhardt]] | cinematography = Jean-Jacques Tarbès | released = {{Film date|1975}} | language = French }}'''''The Gypsy''''' ({{lang-fr|Le Gitan}}, {{lang-it|Lo zingaro}}) is a 1975 French-Italian crime-drama film written and directed by [[José Giovanni]]. It is based on Giovanni's novel ''Histoire de fou''. It recorded admissions of 1,788,111 in France.[http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com.au&sl=fr&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/box-office-alain-delon-c22669761/50&usg=ALkJrhievvifwF4EZ5TJ8-4J0zLVQohZpQ Box office information for film] at Box Office Story ==Plot== {{expand section|date=September 2015}} == Cast == * [[Alain Delon]] as Hugo Sennart, aka Le Gitan * [[Annie Girardot]] as Ninie * [[Paul Meurisse]] as Yan Kuq * [[Marcel Bozzuffi]] as Blot * [[Bernard Giraudeau]] as Mareuil * [[Renato Salvatori]] as Jo Amila * Maurice Barrier as Jacques Helman * [[Maurice Biraud]] as Pierrot le Naïf * Michel Fortin as Marcel * [[Jacques Rispal]] as The Veterinary * [[Florence Giorgetti]] as Ninie's servant * [[Nicolas Vogel]] as Jeannot ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0071557}} [[Category:French films]] [[Category:1975 films]] [[Category:Films based on works by José Giovanni]] [[Category:Films directed by José Giovanni]] [[Category:Films produced by Alain Delon]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]] [[Category:Bank robbery in fiction]] [[Category:Screenplays by José Giovanni]] {{1970s-France-film-stub}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Gypsy, The}}

[[File:Milky Way Project.jpg|thumb|right|The Milky Way Project logo.]] '''The Milky Way Project''' is a [[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]] project whose main goal is to identify [[stellar-wind bubble]]s in the [[Milky Way Galaxy]]. Users classify sets of [[infrared]] images from the [[Spitzer Space Telescope]] and the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer ([[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer|WISE]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/povich/milky-way-project/about/research|title=Zooniverse|website=www.zooniverse.org|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> Scientists believe bubbles in these images are the result of young, massive stars whose light causes shocks in interstellar gas.
[[File:Bubbles Within Bubbles.jpg|thumb|An example of what is called a hierarchical bubble structure, in which one giant bubble, carved into the dust of space by massive stars, has triggered the formation of smaller bubbles]]
==Details==
The Milky Way Project works with data taken from the Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer Galactic Plane Survey (MIPSGAL) and Galactic Legacy Infrared Mid-Plane Survey Extraordinaire (GLIMPSE). Only a small part uses WISE data. The project looks for bubbles, which can mean the formation of stars. The project also looks for knots, star clusters, and other objects such as young stars, [[supernova]] remnants, and newly discovered galaxies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Milky Way Project|url=http://spacehack.org/project/milky-way-project|website=Spacehack|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Milky Way Project: Can you help?|url=http://nightsky.jpl.nasa.gov/news-display.cfm?News_ID=574|website=Night Sky Network|publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory - California Institute of Technology|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>
== History == The Milky Way Project started as the ninth Zooniverse project in December 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.milkywayproject.org/2010/06/26/coming-soon/|title=Coming Soon…|last=Zooniverse|first=The|date=2010-06-26|website=The Milky Way Project Blog|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.milkywayproject.org/2010/12/07/site-goes-live/|title=Site Goes Live|last=ttfnrob|date=2010-12-07|website=The Milky Way Project Blog|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> The ''phase 1'' worked with the colors: 4.5 μm for blue, 8.0 μm for green and 24 μm for red. This resulted in the Data Release 1 (DR1) of the Milky Way Project in 2012 with 5,106 bubbles, which can also be found in [[SIMBAD]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Simpson|first=R. J.|last2=Povich|first2=M. S.|last3=Kendrew|first3=S.|last4=Lintott|first4=C. J.|last5=Bressert|first5=E.|last6=Arvidsson|first6=K.|last7=Cyganowski|first7=C.|last8=Maddison|first8=S.|last9=Schawinski|first9=K.|date=2012-08-21|title=The Milky Way Project First Data Release: A Bubblier Galactic Disk|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=424|issue=4|pages=2442–2460|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20770.x|issn=0035-8711|arxiv = 1201.6357 |bibcode = 2012MNRAS.424.2442S }}</ref>
The ''annulus tool'' that was used to mark the bubbles in the Milky Way Project ''phase 1'' was at random round and needed improvement. This problem was solved after the introduction of the ''ellipse tool''. This new tool was used in the ''phase 2'' of the project, short after DR1. This changed the classification and the tool does fit the actual shape of the bubbles. The phase 2 also used different colors: 3.6 μm for blue, 4.5 μm for green and 8.0 μm for red. The same three colors as [http://aladin.u-strasbg.fr/AladinLite/?target=&fov=3.00&survey=P%2FGLIMPSE360 GLIMPSE 360 in Aladin Lite].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://polyastron.wordpress.com/2016/10/12/a-brief-history-of-the-milky-way-project-why-we-still-need-your-help/ |title=A Brief History of the Milky Way Project: Why We (Still) Need Your Help |author=tharinduj96 |date=2016-10-12 |website=The Milky Way Project Blog |access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> ''Phase 3'' is also called Phoenix since it started after a year offline<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://polyastron.wordpress.com/2016/09/15/the-milky-way-project-phoenix/ |title=The Milky Way Project: Phoenix |last=Povich |first=Matthew S. |date=2016-09-15 |website=The Milky Way Project Blog |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> and it is now active. Phase 3 uses the same colors as phase 1 and the same ellipse tool as phase 2, combining the strength of phase 1+2.
The Milky Way Project did also search for star clusters and galaxies. Phase 2 additionally did search for Extended Green Objects (EGO), 4.5 μm emissions that seem to be connected to [[Astrophysical maser|outflow from massive young stellar objects]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cyganowski|first=C. J.|last2=Whitney|first2=B. A.|last3=Holden|first3=E.|last4=Braden|first4=E.|last5=Brogan|first5=C. L.|last6=Churchwell|first6=E.|last7=Indebetouw|first7=R.|last8=Watson|first8=D. F.|last9=Babler|first9=B. L.|date=2008-12-01|title=A Catalog of Extended Green Objects (EGOs) in the GLIMPSE Survey: A new sample of massive young stellar object outflow candidates|journal=The Astronomical Journal|volume=136|issue=6|pages=2391–2412|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/136/6/2391|issn=0004-6256|arxiv = 0810.0530 |bibcode = 2008AJ....136.2391C }}</ref> The volunteers did mention objects that are compact and yellow in the Milky Way Project. They are now called ''yellow balls'', a mix of compact [[Star formation|star-forming regions]] that show transition into bubbles.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kerton|first=C. R.|last2=Wolf-Chase|first2=G.|last3=Arvidsson|first3=K.|last4=Lintott|first4=C. J.|last5=Simpson|first5=R. J.|date=2015-01-26|title=The Milky Way Project: What are Yellowballs?|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=799|issue=2|pages=153|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/799/2/153|issn=1538-4357|arxiv = 1502.01388 |bibcode = 2015ApJ...799..153K }}</ref> In the phase 3 the volunteers can additionally search for yellowballs, [[Pillars of Creation|pillars]] and [[Bow shocks in astrophysics|bowshocks]]. Phase 3 aims to create a reliable bubble catalog (DR2) with the data from phase 2+3 (4.4 million classifications), an improved yellowball catalog and the largest bowshock catalog to date. For this goal the 24 μm part of the image is important: Bubbles are more easy to spot and bowshocks are most of the time visible at this wavelength. [[File:Runaway-star-zeta-ophiuchi-110125.jpg|thumb|Example of a [[runaway star]] forming an infrared [[Bow shocks in astrophysics|bow shock]]. Here: [[Zeta Ophiuchi]]]] The ''MWP classification aggregation pipeline'' is continuously tested and modified to avoid issues that were encountered in DR1.
==See also== :{{Portal|Astronomy}} Zooniverse projects: {{columns-list|colwidth=15em|style=width: 600px; font-style: italic;| *[[Asteroid Zoo]] *[[Backyard Worlds]] *[[Disk Detective]] *[[Galaxy Zoo]] *[[Old Weather]] *[[Planet Hunters]] *[[SETILive]] }}
== References == <references />
==External links== * [https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/povich/milky-way-project Official Website] * [https://polyastron.wordpress.com/ Milky Way Project Blog] * [https://blog.milkywayproject.org/ Classical Milky Way Project Blog] * [https://talk.milkywayproject.org/ Old Milky Way Project Talk] * [http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR?-source=J/MNRAS/424/2442 Data Release 1] * [http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR-3?-source=J/AJ/136/2391&-out.max=50&-out.form=HTML%20Table&-out.add=_r&-out.add=_RAJ,_DEJ&-sort=_r&-oc.form=sexa GLIMPSE Extended Green Object catalog]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2017}}
[[File:BaliHaiNOLA59Postcard.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|"The Bali Ha'i", a tiki themed restaurant in [[New Orleans]], 1950s [[A-Frame house|A-Frame style]]]] '''Tiki culture''' is a 20th-century theme used in [[Polynesia]]n-style restaurants and clubs originally in the United States and then, to a lesser degree, around the world. Although inspired in part by [[tiki]] carvings and mythology, the connection is loose and stylized, being an American form and not a [[Polynesian art|Polynesian fine art]] form. ==In the United States== [[File:Suffering Bastard Cocktail.jpg|thumb|The Suffering Bastard cocktail, a WWII-era tiki drink, at Latitude 29 in New Orleans]] Tiki culture in the United States began in 1933 with the opening of Don's Beachcomber, later changed to [[Don the Beachcomber]], a Polynesian-themed bar and restaurant in [[Hollywood]].<ref name="Curtis">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/tiki|author=Wayne Curtis|title=Tiki|work=American Heritage|date=August–September 2006|volume=57|issue=4}}</ref> The proprietor was Ernest Raymond Beaumont-Gantt, a young man from [[Texas]] who had sailed throughout the [[Oceania|South Pacific]]; later he legally changed his name to Donn Beach. His restaurant featured [[Cantonese cuisine]] and exotic rum [[Punch (drink)|punches]], with a decor of flaming [[torch]]es, [[rattan]] furniture, flower [[Lei (Hawaii)|lei]]s, and brightly colored fabrics. Three years later, Victor Bergeron, better known as [[Trader Vic]], adopted a tiki theme for his restaurant in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], which eventually grew to become a worldwide chain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradervicspaloalto.com/restaurant/history.html|title=Trader Vics History|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051228110534/http://www.tradervicspaloalto.com/restaurant/history.html|archivedate=2005-12-28|df=}}</ref> The theme took on a life of its own during the restaurant's growth in the Bay Area. The Trader Vic's in [[Palo Alto]] even spawned architectural choices, such as the concept behind the odd-looking Tiki Inn Motel,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.critiki.com/cgi-bin/location.cgi?loc_id=136|title=Tiki Inn Motel in Palo Alto, CA|publisher=}}</ref> which still exists as the Stanford Terrace Inn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stanfordterraceinn.com|title=Stanford Terrace Inn|website=www.stanfordterraceinn.com}}</ref>
California's [[World's Fair]] in 1939 – the [[Golden Gate International Exposition]] – celebrated for the first time [[Polynesian culture]] in the United States. The theme of this fair was "Pageant of the Pacific" primarily showcasing the goods of nations bordering the Pacific Ocean. The theme was physically symbolized by "The Tower of the Sun" and a giant, 80-foot statue of [[Pacifica (statue)|Pacifica]], goddess of the Pacific Ocean.
==Cuisine and cocktails== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2013}} [[File:Mai Tai.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Mai Tai]] is a quintessential tiki cocktail.]] Tiki culture of mid-century America was primarily born in the restaurant industry. Don the Beachcomber's in Hollywood, California, is largely credited as being the first tiki restaurant from which all other eateries and bars "borrowed." Donn Beach, the founder of Don The Beachcomber, is also credited as having created the tropical drink genre singlehandedly.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.donthebeachcomber.com/pages/about-us|title = Our History|date = |accessdate = 21 June 2016|website = Don the Beachcomber|publisher = |last = |first = |location = Huntington Beach, California}}</ref> Beach was the first restaurateur to mix flavored syrups and fresh fruit juices with [[rum]]. These drinks were called Rhum Rhapsodies and made Don the Beachcomber's restaurant the hot spot for Hollywood elite and stars from the 1940s well into the 1960s. By the mid to late 1950s, many restaurateurs had begun to copy, and in some cases, steal Beach's theme, food and cocktails. Many eventually created their own cocktails and signature food dishes based on Asian themes. Beach is credited for having created some of the most memorable exotic cocktails such as the Scorpion and the [[Zombie (cocktail)|Zombie]]. [[Howard Hughes]] was a regular at the Hollywood Don the Beachcomber, as were [[Charlie Chaplin]] and [[Frank Sinatra]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/los-angeles/restaurants/don-the-beachcomber|title=Don the Beachcomber|publisher=}}</ref>
Victor "Trader Vic" Bergeron was a Beach contemporary and the founder of [[Trader Vic's]] restaurant chain. Both created a variety of "Polynesian" dishes, including [[crab Rangoon]] and [[rumaki]].
The [[Mai Tai]] is considered to be the quintessential tiki cocktail. A protracted feud between Beach and Bergeron erupted when both claimed to have invented the Mai Tai.
Most tiki-themed establishments served at least some of their cocktails in ceramic mugs depicting tikis, also known as [[tiki mugs]]. The styles and sizes varied widely. Most restaurants offered their signature drink in a tiki mug that the patron was able to take home. This led to a large number of tiki mugs surviving as souvenirs. Today, the tiki mug is a highly prized find and is considered to be as much a symbol of the tiki culture as a tiki itself.
With the resurgence of tiki culture in the later part of the 1990s, a resurgence in the interest of the original exotic cocktails has grown as well. Jeff "Beachbum" Berry released several drink books containing the recipes for many of the signature drinks from long lost tiki restaurants and bars, as well as classic tiki cocktails from Trader Vic's and Don the Beachcombers.
Today, Trader Vic's is the only major restaurant chain still in operation. However, a new Don The Beachcomber was opened in [[Huntington Beach, California]] in 2009—having taken over Sam's Seafood Restaurant/Kona. Sam's was also a long lived tiki-themed restaurant that dated back to the 1940s. It was sold in 2007 and the name was changed to Kona for a short period before the current owner of the Don The Beachcomber corporate name took it over.
==After World War II== {{unreferenced section|date=August 2017}} When American servicemen returned home from [[World War II]], they brought with them stories and souvenirs from the South Pacific. [[James Michener]] won the 1948 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for his collection of short stories, ''[[Tales of the South Pacific]]'', which in turn was the basis for ''[[South Pacific (musical)|South Pacific]]'', the 1949 musical by [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]], also a Pulitzer Prize winner.
In addition to the returning WWII veterans, several other factors contributed to the mid-century American explosion in Polynesian pop culture or tiki culture. Post-war America saw the rise of the middle class as an economic force. This coupled with ever-increasing affordability of travel, particularly newly established air travel to Hawaii, helped to propel the nation's interest in all things tropical. The excitement surrounding the 1947 [[Kon-Tiki]] expedition helped to promote tiki culture. [[State of Hawaii#U.S. statehood|Hawaiian statehood]] in 1959 was a major factor which further drove the tropical lifestyle popularity, and Americans fell in love with their romanticized version of an exotic culture.
Polynesian design began to infuse every aspect of the country's visual aesthetic, from home accessories to architecture. Single family homes, apartment complexes, business and even large shopping and living districts of some cities were heavily influenced by Polynesian aesthetics. However, by the 1980s, most of the Polynesian aesthetic had been completely wiped away in the name of progress. Nevertheless, some architectural examples of homes, apartments and restaurant buildings remain. A small handful of locations still contain carved tikis.
==Music== Soon came integration of the idea into music by artists like [[Les Baxter]], [[Arthur Lyman]], and [[Martin Denny]], who blended the tiki idea through [[jazz]] augmented with Polynesian, Asian, and Latin instruments and "tropical" themes creating the [[Exotica]] genre. This music blended the elements of [[Afro-Cuban jazz|Afro-Cuban rhythm]]s, unusual instrumentations, environmental sounds, and lush romantic themes from [[Hollywood]] movies, topped off with evocative titles like "Jaguar God", into a cultural hybrid native to nowhere.
There were two primary strains of this kind of [[exotica]]: jungle and tiki. Jungle exotica was a Hollywood creation, with its roots in [[Tarzan]] movies and further back, to [[William Henry Hudson]]'s novel ''[[Green Mansions]]''. Les Baxter was the king of jungle exotica, and spawned a host of imitators.
Tiki exotica was introduced with Martin Denny's Waikiki nightclub jungle noises arrangement of Baxter's ''[[Quiet Village]]''. Tiki rode a wave of popularity in the late 1950s and early 1960s marked by the entrance of [[Hawaii]] as the 50th state in 1959 and the introduction of [[tiki bar]]s and restaurants around the continental United States.
==Television== The visual iconography of the CBS-TV series ''[[Gilligan's Island]]'', which was originally broadcast in 1964-1967, borrowed significantly from tiki culture, with the "castaways" depicted as building huts, furniture, and housewares that resembled elements of fantasy-Polynesian culture presented to Americans by period bars and restaurants.
A 1972 episode of ''[[The Brady Bunch]]'' took place in Hawaii and involved a magical, taboo tiki idol that becomes the center of the plot.
==Revival== The mid-1990s saw the beginning of a revival of the tiki culture and a rise in popularity for traditional tiki cocktails in craft cocktail bars.
Contemporary "[[Lowbrow (art movement)|Lowbrow]]" artists such as [[Shag (artist)|Shag]], [[Mark Ryden]], and Derek Yaniger use tiki imagery in their paintings.
Several books on the subject of tiki have been published, including ''The Book of Tiki'' by Sven Kirsten, published by Taschen.
The revival also spawned ''Tiki Noir'', a literary subgenre of hard-boiled crime fiction in a tiki setting, in which the main character, often a detective, but not always, is world-weary and deeply flawed; ''Ritual of the Savage'' by Jay Strongman being the prime example.{{cn|date=August 2017}}
Tiki-themed events and conventions have begun to spring up across America—with the majority happening in Southern California. Large annual events include Tiki Oasis in San Diego;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tikioasis.com/2015/|title=Tiki Oasis in San Diego|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405060605/http://tikioasis.com/2015/|archivedate=2016-04-05|df=}}</ref> Hukilau in Fort Lauderdale, Tiki Caliente in Palm Springs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiki-caliente.com/|title=Home|first=TIki|last=Caliente|website=TIki Caliente}}</ref> and Ohana: Luau at the Lake in Lake George, NY.
A variety of online communities have formed for tikiphiles. The [[Fraternal Order of Moai]] is also a tiki-themed social organization in the United States.
==Cultural appropriation== The question of whether tiki bars should be considered a type of [[cultural appropriation]] has arisen in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://munchies.vice.com/en_us/article/ezq7n7/tiki-drinking-culture-has-always-been-a-fantasy-but-not-an-easy-one|title=Tiki Drinking Culture Has Always Been a Fantasy, But Not an Easy One|website=Munchies}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://openspace.sfmoma.org/2017/05/abolish-the-tiki-bar/|title=Abolish the Tiki Bar|publisher=}}</ref>
Scholars at the [[University of Exeter]] and [[Claremont Graduate University]] argue that tiki culture's stylish and seemingly innocuous cultural imagery can obscure and subsume native traditions and divert attention from the history of violent [[colonialism]] in the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ore.exeter.ac.uk/repository/bitstream/handle/10036/33395/manag0502.pdf|title=Packaging Paradise:Organizing Representations of Hawaii}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://scholarship.claremont.edu/lux/vol2/iss1/21/|title=Tiki Kitsch, American Appropriation, and the Disappearance of the Pacific Islander Body}}</ref>
==See also== <!-- Please keep entries in alphabetical order & add a short description [[WP:SEEALSO]] --> *[[Disney's Polynesian Village Resort]] *[[Exoticism]] *[[Kava culture]] **[[Kava bar]] *[[Lounge music]] *[[Tiki Bar TV]] *[[Walt Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room]] <!-- please keep entries in alphabetical order -->
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Sven A. Kirsten: ''The Book of Tiki''. Taschen 2003, {{ISBN|3-8228-2433-X}} *Sven A. Kirsten: ''Tiki Modern and the Wild World of Witco''. Taschen 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-8228-4717-6}} *Duke Carter: ''Tiki Quest''. Pegboard Press (August 2003), {{ISBN|0-9743283-0-8}} *Jay Strongman: ''Ritual of the Savage'', Hungry Eye Books 2015, {{ISBN|978-0993186615}} *Jay Strongman: ''Tiki Mugs: Cult Artifacts of Polynesian Pop''. 2008, [http://www.koreropress.com/tiki-mugs-cult-artifacts-of-polynesian-pop/ Korero Books], {{ISBN|978-0-9553398-1-3}} *James Teitelbaum: ''Tiki Road Trip''. Santa Monica Press (May 1, 2003), {{ISBN|1-891661-30-2}}; 2nd edition released June 1, 2007. *Otto Von Stroheim, Robert Williams: ''Tiki Art Now! A Volcanic Eruption of Art''. Last Gasp (November 10, 2004), {{ISBN|0-86719-627-0}} * Jeff Berry: "Sippin' Safari: In Search of the Great "Lost" Tropical Drink Recipes... and the People Behind Them". SLG Publishing 2007, {{ISBN|978-1-59362-067-7}} *Phillip S. Roberts: "Waikiki Tiki: Art, History, and Photographs." Bess Press 2010, {{ISBN|978-1573063111}}
==External links== {{External links|section|date=June 2017}}<!-- most of the links seem unrelated or loosely related --> {{Commons category}} * [http://www.maori.org.nz/ Maori History & Culture] * [http://www.huapala.org/ Hawaiian Music and Hula Archives] * [http://www.mythichawaii.com/ Hawaiian and Tiki culture] * [http://blog.retroplanet.com/tiki-design-revival Revival of Tiki Culture] * [https://www.pbs.org/wayfinders/polynesian.html "Wayfinders: Polynesian History & Origin"] – [[PBS]] * [http://www.taulapapa.com/artist_statement.html "Tiki Manifesto", poem by Dan Taulapapa McMullin]
